results.headline: In a Vicious Sadist, the Faintest Glimmer of Soul
results.summary_short: “Pieta,” a brutal drama by the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk, centers on a violent loan shark approached by a woman claiming to be his mother.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pieta

results.headline: If 27 Is Old, How Old Is Grown Up?
results.summary_short: Greta Gerwig is the co-writer and star of “Frances Ha,” a look at a vaguely artistic, post-collegiate New York cohort, directed by Noah Baumbach.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frances Ha

results.headline: Doctor and Patient: A Gothic Love Story
results.summary_short: Alice Winocour’s “Augustine” depicts the relationship between the 19th-century French neurologist Jean-Martin Charcot and a young housemaid who becomes his patient.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Augustine

results.headline: An Intrepid Foundling and Her Unlikely Mentor
results.summary_short: In “33 Postcards,” directed by Pauline Chan, a heart-tugging Chinese orphan develops a relationship with her far-off sponsor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 33 Postcards

results.headline: That Elusive Seat at the U.N. Table
results.summary_short: “State 194” explores the Palestinian Authority’s struggle for a two-state solution and member status at the United Nations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of State 194

results.headline: Keeping Kosher in Nigeria, a Tiny but Fervent Minority
results.summary_short: The documentary “Re-emerging: The Jews of Nigeria” focuses on a minority that claims to be descended from ancient Israelites.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Re-emerging: The Jews of Nigeria

results.headline: Outrunning Assassins, Sulky Daughter in Tow
results.summary_short: In “Erased,” directed by Philipp Stölzl, a former C.I.A. operative flees with his estranged teenage daughter after he finds himself a death target.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Erased

results.headline: A Last Stand for Nature Against Mighty Odds
results.summary_short: The documentary “Elemental” follows a water expert in India, an Australian inventor and a Canadian activist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elemental

results.headline: Battle of the Bullhorns as a Wind Project Beckons
results.summary_short: “Cape Spin” examines the fierce struggle over a proposed wind farm off the Massachusetts coast.
results.display_title: Cape Spin: An American Power Struggle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cape Spin: An American Power Struggle

results.headline: Just Us Girls, They Thought. Oops.
results.summary_short: In “Black Rock,” three young women decide to reconnect on an isolated island in Maine, only to find themselves running for their lives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Rock

results.headline: Sudden Impulse, and a Warrior Is Born
results.summary_short: The documentary “Bidder 70” focuses on Tim DeChristopher, who would serve time in prison for disrupting a federal auction of oil and gas drilling rights in Utah.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bidder 70

results.headline: Kirk and Spock, in Their Roughhousing Days
results.summary_short: In “Star Trek Into Darkness,” the U.S.S. Enterprise crew hunts for a terrorist in the latest film in the franchise.

results.headline: A Scruffy Hound That Money Can’t Buy
results.summary_short: “Old Dog,” by the novelist and director Pema Tseden, centers on a tug of war over a Tibetan mastiff.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Old Dog

results.headline: An Opera Star, Freckles, Blemishes and All
results.summary_short: “Becoming Traviata” follows the soprano Natalie Dessay through rehearsals in this documentary directed by Philippe Béziat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Becoming Traviata

results.headline: One Mistake, and a Life Derails
results.summary_short: A young man, however protected by his Irish community, is eaten by guilt in “What Richard Did,” featuring Jack Reynor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Richard Did

results.headline: Far From China’s Bustling Cities, the Grind of Poverty
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Three Sisters,” the director Wang Bing focuses on an impoverished farmer’s family, including the 10-year-old daughter left behind to fend for herself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Three Sisters

results.headline: Playing Jazz in High Heels and Skirts
results.summary_short: “The Girls in the Band” tells the story of women faced with racism and sexist male musicians in the 1930s and ’40s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girls in the Band

results.headline: Family Opens Its Diary, With Mother as Subject
results.summary_short: In “Stories We Tell,” the actress and director Sarah Polley sat down with relatives and friends to talk about her mother, who died when Ms. Polley was 11.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stories We Tell

results.headline: Champions Face Challenges, Too
results.summary_short: The documentary “Venus and Serena” focuses on 2011, a year when the sisters’ domination of women’s tennis seemed threatened.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Venus & Serena

results.headline: Wartime Enemies Do an About-Face in Peacetime
results.summary_short: In “The Second Meeting,” a documentary, an American stealth-bomber pilot shot down over Serbia meets his enemy a dozen years later, in peace, and in friendship.
